subject: Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: This is very valuable practical information. It is also evidence that using Roe for both r and NURSE maybe viable. Furthermore, it may show omitting vowels is
messageBody:
This is very valuable practical information. It is also evidence that
using Roe for both r and NURSE maybe viable. Furthermore, it may show
omitting vowels is a viable plan in areas beyond just Ing and Roe.
I'd never advocate dropping vowels just because I could but any case
where doing so conveys a significant benefit and does no harm should
be seriously looked at I think.

I too hold QM most holy but there has now been many decades of user
experience and progress in linguistics which I too think we should
take into account.



--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Moira O'Brien" <mj@...> wrote:
>
> In my writing experience I have found that I often omit the vowel
completely
> in endings. So captain becomes kAptn. This effectively removes the
need for
> the indefinite vowel and I dont think it makes reading more difficult. I
> have done this since the early days even though it goes beyond QM.
>
> Photography, photograph, photographer  I would use utter in the
first and
> third, but the first syllable of two I would stress & so use Owe.
>
> Moira
>
>
>
>
>
> On 21/11/2007, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
> >
> > Anthony Grahn scripsit:
> >
> > > 1. COMMA
> > > Do not use the letter Utter for COMMA. Indeed do not have any letter
> > > represent the indefinite vowel. Instead write the letter for the
> > > sound the vowel has when it is stressed in that same root. Write the
> > > "mental image" of the sound as it were. (sometimes of course this
> > > turns out to be /V/ in which case one will use Utter after all (see
> > > below))
> >
> > Except, of course, that some roots have unstressed syllables to
which the
> > stress never shifts. Consider "captain": in "captaincy", "captainess",
> > "captainless", "captainry", "captainship", the "ain" never gets the
> > stress, so what vowel to use? As pronounced, some use Utter, some use
> > It, for some it's impossible to say which they use. TO helpfully tells
> > us that the pronunciation was once that of FACE, but no accent has
used
> > FACE in that syllable for centuries.
> >
> > Looking nearby in the dictionary, I find "capsule" and "caramel" and
> > "carom" all behaving the same way. No, if we go this route, we are
> > truly doing TO with funny-looking symbols.
> >
> > > - This has some whopping great advantages for morphemic writing:
many
> > > roots will no longer vary when suffixes are added:
> > > e.g.
> > > with the old approach we had:
> > > photography, photograph, photographer
> > > Fee+Owe+Tea+Ox+Gay+Roe...
> > > Fee+Owe+Tea+UTTER+Gay+Roe...
> > > Fee+Owe+Tea+Ox+Gay+Roe...
> >
> > I distinctly have Utter in the first syllable in all three words; it
> > looks like you're anticipating your argument a bit here.
> >
> > > Thus: make Roe cover /r/ *and* the lexical set NURSE (which
implies /3/
> > )
> >
> > I like this, except of course that it's explicitly un-Read. While
we are
> > at it, we could similarly ditch Utter in words like "bottle",
"bottom",
> > "button"; it adds nothing.
> >
> > > My only concern is that this may be trouble for accents that
strongly
> > > roll their Rs; a rolled r is very different than /3/ and could
be too
> > > much to ask of them to use one letter for both.
> >
> > Scotland never had the fir/fur/fern merger, so they have worse
> > problems than this.
> >
> > --
> > The Imperials are decadent, 300 pound John Cowan
<cowan@...<cowan%40ccil.org>
> > >
> > free-range chickens (except they have http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> > teeth, arms instead of wings, and
> > dinosaurlike tails). --Elyse Grasso
> >
> >
>
>
>
> --
